HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 8, 1924

WOODROW WILSON
Woodrow Wilson received his A. B. at Princeton. Princeton,
however, cannot claim him. He received his Ph. D. at Johns' Hopkins; but Hopkins cannot claim him. Wilson belonged to America
and America mourns his loss as the rest of the world bows its head
in tribute.
Although Hopkins cannot point to Mr. Wilson as their own, they
can take a certain amount of pride in him and in his achievements.
Contemporary press notices term him as "imperialistic," as "dictatorial," as "idealistic." And still we are proud of him. We feel
that although, at present, much of the good that he accomplished is
"interred with his bones," it will arise and history will view Woodrow
Wilson as one of the great of the great Americans. We are glad
that Johns Hopkins is able to claim even a small part of his reflected
glory.
Mr. Wilson may have had his faults. It may be that the allegation that he was "dictatorial" is true. He was undoubtedly "idealistic." Throughout the years of his Presidency, however, he was
striving for the good of his country and for the good of mankind.
He thought that he had found a cure that would eliminate one of
the greatest evils of humanity. And he gave his life while endeavoring to tender this supposed solution to an unsympathetic, unbelieving
and unresponsive nation.
It is for posterity alone to pass judgment upon Woodrow Wilson
as a statesman. We, the undergraduates of Johns Hopkins University, can only say that we are proud of him and proud of his connection with Hopkins. And with the rest of the world we bow our
heads in admiration and in sorrow.

Following the forming of the arc,
there was a demonstration of the
efficiency of the horn gap. A 15foot horn was constructed and an
arc was induced at a potential of
200,000 volts. The arc rose slowly,
due to the hot air produced with a
tearing noise, to the end of the
horn, blew out and immediately reestablished at the base. It rose
again and again until the circuit
was opened. This self-extinguishing feature is used daily on power
systems to relieve surges and lightning strokes. This is a spectacular
test and is an exhibition that witnesses do not soon forget.
The next tests, were insulator
flashovers. In these tests a dry insulator post, built up of several
units, was flashed over a potential
of 800,000 volts. Following this,
the column was covered with a
heavy water spray to approximate
conditions during a torrential rainstorm, and it flashed over a potential of 650,000 volts, showing the
wet insulator to be over 80 per
cent as efficient as the dry insulator. This was a remarkably high
ratio and attributed to excellent design.

THE EVILS OF EXAMINATIONS?
Mid-years have come and gone and have, left in their wake the
annual toll. Despite the fact that the period of time devoted to
examinations was materially lengthened, indications seem to show
that the casualty list is as great, if not greater, than usual. Rumors
are numerous at this time but it seems probable that a number of
undergraduates have been ejected by means of the automatic threefailure route.
Recently, in commenting upon the lengthening of the examination
period, the NEWS-LETTER said: "Failures under the new system can be
due only to inherent stupidity or lack of application." And, allowing
for inevitable exceptions, we repeat this. The evils attached to the
present system may be numerous; the strain may be great; the
results may not be in proportion to the worth of the individual student. We fail to see, however, how a man of average intelligence
who has prepared methodically could fall below passing mark in
three examinations.
Whatever excuses the unfortunates may present to the Board
.of Collegiate Studies, they cannot reasonably attribute their misfortune to the "evils of examinations."

he exploded some of the outstanding errors
of thirteenth century thought. Because of
his advanced teachings, Bacon spent many
years of his life in prison.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 8, 1924

WOODROW WILSON
Woodrow Wilson received his A. B. at Princeton. Princeton,
however, cannot claim him. He received his Ph. D. at Johns' Hopkins; but Hopkins cannot claim him. Wilson belonged to America
and America mourns his loss as the rest of the world bows its head
in tribute.
Although Hopkins cannot point to Mr. Wilson as their own, they
can take a certain amount of pride in him and in his achievements.
Contemporary press notices term him as "imperialistic," as "dictatorial," as "idealistic." And still we are proud of him. We feel
that although, at present, much of the good that he accomplished is
"interred with his bones," it will arise and history will view Woodrow
Wilson as one of the great of the great Americans. We are glad
that Johns Hopkins is able to claim even a small part of his reflected
glory.
Mr. Wilson may have had his faults. It may be that the allegation that he was "dictatorial" is true. He was undoubtedly "idealistic." Throughout the years of his Presidency, however, he was
striving for the good of his country and for the good of mankind.
He thought that he had found a cure that would eliminate one of
the greatest evils of humanity. And he gave his life while endeavoring to tender this supposed solution to an unsympathetic, unbelieving
and unresponsive nation.
It is for posterity alone to pass judgment upon Woodrow Wilson
as a statesman. We, the undergraduates of Johns Hopkins University, can only say that we are proud of him and proud of his connection with Hopkins. And with the rest of the world we bow our
heads in admiration and in sorrow.

THE EVILS OF EXAMINATIONS?
Mid-years have come and gone and have, left in their wake the
annual toll. Despite the fact that the period of time devoted to
examinations was materially lengthened, indications seem to show
that the casualty list is as great, if not greater, than usual. Rumors
are numerous at this time but it seems probable that a number of
undergraduates have been ejected by means of the automatic threefailure route.
Recently, in commenting upon the lengthening of the examination
period, the NEWS-LETTER said: "Failures under the new system can be
due only to inherent stupidity or lack of application." And, allowing
for inevitable exceptions, we repeat this. The evils attached to the
present system may be numerous; the strain may be great; the
results may not be in proportion to the worth of the individual student. We fail to see, however, how a man of average intelligence
who has prepared methodically could fall below passing mark in
three examinations.
Whatever excuses the unfortunates may present to the Board
.of Collegiate Studies, they cannot reasonably attribute their misfortune to the "evils of examinations."
